metadata.titleEn: 30m resolution burned area products over the Tibetan Plateau (2020)
metadata.description: The dataset is the 30m resolution burned area product of 2020 over the Tibetan Plateau. The dataset is produced using Landsat time series land surface reflectance and machine learning algorithm, and the overall accuracy is over 90%. It can provide data product support for the research and applications in fire monitoring, carbon emission studies, ecological environment monitoring, global change research and other fields.
metadata.instructions: The burned area data product uses longitude and latitude projection, with a spaital resolution of 0.00025 ° (about 30 meters), and is stored in GeoTIFF format. For the pixel value, 1 represents the burned area pixel, and the null value represents the non burned area pixel.

authorList.unitEn: Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Aerospace Information Innovation

literatureList.titleEn: Long Tengfei, Zhang Zhaoming, He Guojin, et al. 30 m Resolution Global Annual Burned Area Mapping Based on Landsat Images and Google Earth Engine. Remote Sensing, 2019, 11:489-519.
literatureList.referenceEn: Long, T.F., Zhang, Z.M., & He, G.J., et al. (2019). 30 m Resolution Global Annual Burned Area Mapping Based on Landsat Images and Google Earth Engine. Remote Sensing, 11, 489-519.

background: Accurate and complete data of ﬁre locations and Burned areas (BA) are important for a variety of applications including quantifying trends and patterns of ﬁre occurrence and assessing the impacts of ﬁres on a range of natural and social systems, e.g., simulating carbon emissions from biomass burning. Remotely-sensed satellite imagery has been widely used to generate burned area products. Burned area products at the global scale using satellite images have been mostly based on coarse spatial resolution data such as Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR), Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite (GOES), VEGETATION, or Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) images. The recently released Fire_cci product was produced based on MODIS images and has the highest spatial resolution (250 m) of all the existing global BA products, and it can greatly support global climate modeling at moderate resolution thanks to its promising results. However, owing to the growing availability of satellite images of higher resolution, the requirement of BA products derived from those images is also increasing as these products can provide more detailed perimeters of BA, as well as small burned patches. For instance, imagery collected by the family of Landsat sensors is useful and appropriate for monitoring the extent of BA and provides spatial and temporal resolutions ideal for science and management applications. Landsat sensors can provide a longer temporal record (from the 1970s until now) of burned area relative to existing global BA products and potentially with increased accuracy and spatial detail in most areas on the Earth. In summary, global BA products are only available at coarse spatial resolution, while 30-m resolution burned area products are limited to speciﬁc regions. One of the difﬁculties in producing Landsat-based BA products is that the traditional approaches successfully applied to extract global BA from MODIS, VEGETATION, etc., do not work well due to the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors. Moreover, the analysis of post-ﬁre reﬂectance may be easily contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in Tropical regions. However, thanks to Google Earth Engine (GEE), a new generation of cloud computing platforms with access to a huge catalog of satellite imagery and global-scale analysis capabilities, it is now possible to perform global-scale geospatial analysis efﬁciently as the pre-processing of satellite images becomes more user-friendly.
research objective: In this study, however, we focus on an automated global burned area mapping approach based on Landsat images. By utilizing the huge catalog of satellite imagery, as well as the high-performance computing capacity of Google Earth Engine, we propose an automated pipeline for generating 30-m resolution global-scale annual burned area maps from time-series of Landsat images, and a novel 30-m resolution Global annual Burned Area Map of 2015 (GABAM 2015) was released.
challenges: One of the difﬁculties in producing Landsat-based BA products is that the traditional approaches successfully applied to extract global BA from MODIS, VEGETATION, etc., do not work well due to the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors. Moreover, the analysis of post-ﬁre reﬂectance may be easily contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in Tropical regions.
methods: All the available Landsat-8 images during 2014–2015 and various spectral indices were utilized to calculate the burned probability of each pixel using random decision forests, which were globally trained with stratiﬁed (considering both ﬁre frequency and type of land cover) samples, and a seed-growing approach was conducted to shape the ﬁnal burned areas after several carefully-designed logical ﬁlters (NDVI ﬁlter, Normalized Burned Ratio (NBR) ﬁlter, and temporal ﬁlter). The Random Forest (RF) algorithm provided by GEE was applied to train a decision forest classiﬁer, and the global training data consisted of 6735 burned and 6146 unburned samples, which were manually collected from 120 Landsat scenes generated by stratiﬁed random sampling. For the purpose of burned area mapping, 6 bands of the Landsat-8 image were used, i.e., three visible bands (blue, 0.452–0.512 µm; green, 0.533–0.590 µm; red, 0.636–0.673 µm), Near Infrared band (NIR, 0.851–0.879 µm), and two Short Wave Infrared bands (SWIR1, 1.566–1.651µm; SWIR2, 2.107–2.294 µm).
dataset: In this study, all the available Landsat images during 2014–2015 were the main data source used for global BA mapping. The Quality Assessment (QA) band of Landsat image, which was generated by the FMaskalgorithm, was used to perform QA masking. Validation: Commonly, when satellite data are used as reference data, they should have higher spatial resolution than the data used to generate the BA product. Consequently, in this study, some publicly-available satellite images of higher-resolution were utilized, while Landsat comprised the majority of the validation data source. Speciﬁcally, Landsat-8 (LC8) images were employed to generate reference data independently for most of the validation sites except those located in the United States (U.S.), South America, and China.
findings: Cross-comparison with the recent Fire_cci Version 5.0 BA product found a similar spatial distribution and a strong correlation (R2 = 0.74) between the burned areas from the two products, although differences were found in speciﬁc land cover categories (particularly in agriculture land). Preliminary global validation showed the commission and omission errors of GABAM 2015 to be 13.17% and 30.13%, respectively.

Disjunctive.Question: Which machine learning algorithm is more commonly used for generating high-resolution burned area products, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, or Neural Networks?
For validating burned area datasets, is it more common to use Landsat images, Sentinel images, or other high-resolution satellite data?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used for generating 30-m resolution burned area products on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Where are the challenges in producing Landsat-based burned area products most prominent?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a machine learning algorithm used for generating high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery?
Example.Answer: A machine learning algorithm used for generating high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery is the Random Forest algorithm. It was applied to train a decision forest classifier utilizing Landsat-8 images and was globally trained with stratified samples to calculate the burned probability of each pixel.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using Landsat imagery for burned area mapping?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when using Landsat imagery for burned area mapping is the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors, which makes traditional approaches applied to extract global burned areas from other data like MODIS less effective. Additionally, post-fire reflectance analysis can be contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, especially in tropical regions.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to validate burned area mapping results?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to validate burned area mapping results is the combination of higher-resolution satellite images publicly available, along with a majority of validation data sourced from Landsat-8 images. These were used to independently generate reference data for most validation sites, except in specific regions like the United States, South America, and China.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes of burned area products that are derived from higher resolution satellite imagery like Landsat?
Feature Specification.Answer: 30-meter spatial resolution, detailed perimeters of burned areas, ability to detect small burned patches, spectral indices, machine learning algorithms, burned probability for each pixel

Feature Specification.Question: What are some of the challenges faced in producing burned area products using Landsat images?
Feature Specification.Answer: limited temporal resolution, contamination by clouds, quick vegetation recovery, need for high-resolution reference data

Quantification.Question: What is the overall accuracy percentage of the 30-m resolution burned area products developed using machine learning techniques?
How many Landsat scenes were used to manually collect training samples for the random forest classifier?
What is the percentage of commission and omission errors found in the preliminary global validation of the GABAM 2015 dataset?

Definition.Question: What does 'burned area product' mean in the context of satellite data collection?
Definition.Answer: A 'burned area product' refers to data generated from satellite imagery that maps the extent and location of areas affected by fire. These products are important for various applications such as monitoring fire occurrence, assessing ecological impacts, and simulating carbon emissions. They are typically derived from remotely-sensed satellite images and can vary in spatial resolution depending on the satellite sensor used.

Definition.Question: What is a 'random forest' algorithm in the context of generating burned area maps?
Definition.Answer: In the context of generating burned area maps, a 'random forest' algorithm is a machine learning technique used to classify satellite image pixels as burned or unburned. It involves training a decision forest classifier using a large set of labeled samples and applying various spectral indices to calculate the burned probability of each pixel. The algorithm benefits from the high computational capacity of platforms like Google Earth Engine to process large datasets efficiently.

Definition.Question: What does 'Landsat-based BA product' entail in terms of data collection challenges?
Definition.Answer: A 'Landsat-based BA product' involves using Landsat satellite imagery to map burned areas. The challenges in data collection for such products include limited temporal resolution of Landsat sensors, potential contamination of post-fire reflectance data by clouds, and quick vegetation recovery. These factors make it difficult to apply traditional approaches used for other satellite data like MODIS. However, advancements in cloud computing platforms like Google Earth Engine help mitigate some of these challenges by providing more efficient data processing capabilities.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using Landsat sensors for burned area mapping compare to other satellite-based approaches, such as those using MODIS or VEGETATION data, in terms of spatial resolution and temporal analysis?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection using Landsat sensors offers higher spatial resolution (30-m) compared to MODIS or VEGETATION, which are based on coarser spatial resolution data. However, Landsat's limited temporal resolution can pose challenges, especially in regions with quick vegetation recovery or cloud contamination.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of contamination by clouds and vegetation recovery differ when analyzing post-fire reflectance using Landsat images compared to higher-resolution satellite data?
Comparison.Answer: Landsat images can be more easily contaminated by clouds or quick vegetation recovery, especially in tropical regions, due to their limited temporal resolution. Higher-resolution satellite data might provide more accurate post-fire reflectance analysis by offering finer spatial detail and potentially more frequent temporal coverage, reducing the impact of these challenges.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using machine learning algorithms like random forests in the development of high-resolution burned area products, and how might they improve data interpretation in fire monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: Machine learning algorithms such as random forests play a significant role in developing high-resolution burned area products by enabling the processing of large amounts of satellite imagery data to identify burned areas accurately. These algorithms allow for more detailed data interpretation in fire monitoring by providing higher precision in mapping burned perimeters and capturing smaller burned patches, which are often missed by traditional methods. The use of such algorithms can lead to better accuracy in fire detection and improved understanding of fire dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the integration of higher-resolution satellite images enhance the validation process for burned area datasets, and what potential improvements could this bring to global BA product accuracy?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of higher-resolution satellite images into the validation process for burned area datasets can significantly enhance the accuracy and reliability of these products. Higher-resolution images provide more detailed ground truth data that can be used to validate and refine the mapping algorithms, reducing commission and omission errors. This improvement could lead to more accurate global burned area products, which would better support applications in fire monitoring, carbon emissions estimation, and ecological impact assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limited availability of 30-m resolution burned area products to specific regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limited availability of 30-m resolution burned area products is caused by the traditional approaches' ineffectiveness when applied to Landsat data due to its limited temporal resolution. Furthermore, challenges such as cloud contamination and rapid vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions, add to the difficulty in producing these high-resolution products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do traditional methods used for extracting global burned areas from MODIS or VEGETATION data not work well with Landsat sensors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional methods used for extracting global burned areas from MODIS or VEGETATION data do not work well with Landsat sensors because of Landsat's limited temporal resolution. Additionally, the analysis of post-fire reflectance is often contaminated by clouds or is weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions, making it challenging to apply these traditional methods effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the increased need for burned area products derived from higher-resolution satellite images?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The increased need for burned area products derived from higher-resolution satellite images is driven by their ability to provide more detailed perimeters of burned areas and to detect small burned patches. This demand is also fueled by the growing availability of high-resolution satellite images, which offer better spatial detail and accuracy compared to coarser resolution global products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of incorporating Google Earth Engine's cloud computing platform in global-scale geospatial analysis for burned area mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating Google Earth Engine's cloud computing platform in global-scale geospatial analysis can make the preprocessing of satellite images more user-friendly and enable efficient global-scale analysis, thus facilitating the generation of high-resolution burned area maps.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of utilizing random forest algorithms for generating high-resolution burned area products using Landsat images?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to develop a 30-meter resolution burned area product by leveraging time-series Landsat surface reflectance and sensitive spectral parameters. Random forest algorithms enable the creation of detailed perimeters and identification of small burned patches, offering increased spatial accuracy and detail for science and management applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to focus on high-resolution burned area mapping at a regional scale, such as the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, rather than relying solely on global coarse-resolution products?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High-resolution mapping, such as the 30-meter resolution for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, provides more detailed information on burned areas, which is crucial for understanding local fire dynamics, ecological impacts, and supporting applications such as fire monitoring and carbon emission studies. Global coarse-resolution products may miss smaller patches and lack spatial detail.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of using platforms like Google Earth Engine for the creation and analysis of burned area datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Google Earth Engine offers high-performance cloud computing capabilities and access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery, enabling efficient global-scale geospatial analysis. This facilitates the development of automated pipelines for generating high-resolution burned area maps, overcoming limitations such as cloud contamination and rapid vegetation recovery in post-fire reflectance analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to validate the accuracy of burned area products generated from Landsat images?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation involves using higher-resolution satellite images as reference data, ensuring that these images are more detailed than those used for generating the product. Landsat-8 images are primarily used for validation, except in regions like the U.S., South America, and China, where other sources are also considered.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the development of high-resolution burned area products at a 30-meter scale?
Enablement.Answer: The development of high-resolution burned area products at a 30-meter scale has been enabled by the availability of time-series Landsat imagery, the application of machine learning algorithms such as random forests, and the cloud computing capabilities of platforms like Google Earth Engine, which provide access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery and facilitate large-scale geospatial analyses.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in machine learning algorithms enhance the accuracy and precision of burned area mapping in remote sensing?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in machine learning algorithms, such as the use of random decision forests, enhance the accuracy and precision of burned area mapping by allowing for the incorporation of diverse spectral indices and the processing of large datasets to calculate burned probabilities, leading to improved spatial resolution and the ability to identify smaller burned areas with greater detail.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the integration of cloud computing platforms facilitate the processing and analysis of satellite imagery for global burned area mapping?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of cloud computing platforms like Google Earth Engine facilitates the processing and analysis of satellite imagery by providing high-performance computing resources, user-friendly pre-processing tools, and access to extensive satellite data archives, enabling efficient and scalable global burned area mapping despite challenges such as limited temporal resolution and cloud contamination.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional approaches used for global burned area extraction not meet expectations when applied to higher resolution images such as those from Landsat sensors?
Expectation.Answer: One difficulty is the limited temporal resolution of Landsat sensors, which affects the analysis of post-fire reflectance that may be contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, especially in Tropical regions.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges when using higher-resolution satellite imagery for creating burned area products compared to coarser resolution datasets?
Expectation.Answer: While higher-resolution imagery can provide more detailed perimeters of burned areas and small burned patches, traditional methods may not perform well due to the limited temporal resolution of such imagery and potential contamination from clouds or quick vegetation recovery.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of cloud computing platforms like Google Earth Engine be expected to improve the process of generating global burned area maps from high-resolution satellite images?
Expectation.Answer: Google Earth Engine offers access to a large catalog of satellite imagery and global-scale analysis capabilities, making the pre-processing of satellite images more user-friendly, which allows for efficient global-scale geospatial analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using random forest algorithms for generating high-resolution burned area products from satellite imagery?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of random forest algorithms is effective for generating high-resolution burned area products, as evidenced by the development of a 30-meter resolution product using Landsat images. This method achieved an overall accuracy of over 90%, indicating its robustness in handling large datasets and capturing detailed burned area perimeters.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you anticipate in utilizing Landsat images for burned area mapping, particularly concerning temporal resolution and data quality?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include the limited temporal resolution of Landsat images, which can hinder the detection of burned areas compared to sensors like MODIS. Additionally, post-fire reflectance analysis may face contamination from clouds or rapid vegetation recovery, complicating accurate mapping in certain regions, especially tropical areas.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how higher resolution satellite imagery can improve the accuracy of burned area products in fire monitoring.
Assertion.Answer: Higher resolution satellite imagery, such as Landsat images with 30-m resolution, can provide more detailed perimeters of burned areas and detect smaller burned patches compared to coarser resolution data. This increased spatial detail helps in achieving higher accuracy and spatial detail for monitoring the extent of burned areas.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why traditional approaches for global burned area extraction don't work well with Landsat sensors.
Assertion.Answer: Traditional approaches for global burned area extraction struggle with Landsat sensors due to their limited temporal resolution. The analysis of post-fire reflectance may also be contaminated by clouds or affected by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in tropical regions, making it challenging to apply these methods effectively.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how Google Earth Engine supports the generation of high-resolution burned area maps.
Assertion.Answer: Google Earth Engine supports the generation of high-resolution burned area maps by providing access to a vast catalog of satellite imagery and global-scale analysis capabilities. It allows for efficient global-scale geospatial analysis by making pre-processing of satellite images more user-friendly, facilitating the development of automated pipelines for generating detailed burned area maps.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges associated with using Landsat images for burned area mapping and suggest potential solutions or alternative methods to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the difficulties in producing Landsat-based burned area products is the limited temporal resolution of the Landsat sensors, which makes traditional approaches less effective. Additionally, the analysis of post-fire reflectance can be contaminated by clouds or weakened by quick vegetation recovery, particularly in Tropical regions. Utilizing cloud computing platforms like Google Earth Engine, which allows access to a huge catalog of satellite imagery and global-scale analysis capabilities, can help overcome these challenges. This platform simplifies pre-processing and enables efficient global-scale geospatial analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the potential applications and implications of using higher-resolution satellite imagery for global burned area mapping.
Request/Directive.Answer: Higher-resolution satellite imagery, such as Landsat, offers the potential for more detailed perimeters of burned areas and the identification of small burned patches, which can improve the accuracy and spatial detail of burned area mapping compared to coarser resolution products. This can enhance applications in fire monitoring, carbon emission simulations, and ecological studies. However, challenges such as cloud contamination and rapid post-fire vegetation recovery need to be addressed to fully leverage the benefits of higher-resolution imagery.
